interface is either an address, or an interface name. If interface is an address, it
 sets source address to specified interface address. If interface in an interface name,
 it sets source interface to specified interface. NOTE: For IPv6, when doing ping to a
 link-local scope address, link specification (by the '%'-notation in destination, or
 by this option) can be used but it is no longer required.

Explanations about Options.-t:
Run the command with an SELinux security context that includes the specified
 type. If no type is specified, the default type is derived from the role.
Explanations about Options.-p:
Use a custom password prompt with optional escape sequences. The following
 percent (‘%’) escape sequences are supported by the sudoers policy:
Explanations about Options.-s:
Run the shell specified by the SHELL environment variable if it is set or the
 shell specified by the invoking user's password database entry. If a command is
 specified, it is passed to the shell for execution via the shell's -c option.
 If no command is specified, an interactive shell is executed. Note that most
 shells behave differently when a command is specified as compared to an
 interactive session; consult the shell's manual for details.
Explanations about Options.-A:
Normally, if sudo requires a password, it will read it from the user's terminal.
 If the -A (askpass) option is specified, a (possibly graphical) helper program
 is executed to read the user's password and output the password to the standard
 output. If the SUDO_ASKPASS environment variable is set, it specifies the path
 to the helper program. Otherwise, if sudo.conf(5) contains a line specifying
 the askpass program, that value will be used. For example:

ul_407214: sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1

ifconfig tun0 inet 10.0.0.1/30 up
sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1
ip route add default dev tun0 table John
ip rule add from all lookup John
ip rule add from 10.0.0.2 lookup main priority 500
iptables -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o wlp2s0 -s 10.0.0.2 -j MASQUERADE

sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.tun0.rp_filter=0
# It won't work without also changing the "all" value
sysctl -w net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter=0

ul_119726: strace -f -e trace=network -s 10000 PROCESS ARGUMENTS

strace -p $( pgrep application_name) -f -e trace=network -s 10000

Explanations about Options.-p:
Attach to the process with the process ID pid and begin tracing. The trace
 may be terminated at any time by a keyboard interrupt signal (CTRL-C). strace
 will respond by detaching itself from the traced process(es) leaving it (them)
 to continue running. Multiple -p options can be used to attach to many
 processes in addition to command (which is optional if at least one -p option
 is given). -p "`pidof PROG`" syntax is supported.

#!/bin/bash
date >> /tmp/iptables-cmd.log
ps -f $PPID >> /tmp/iptables-cmd.log
/sbin/iptables $*

Explanations about Options.-f:
Do full-format listing. This option can be combined with many other UNIX-style
 options to add additional columns. It also causes the command arguments to be
 printed. When used with -L, the NLWP (number of threads) and LWP (thread ID)
 columns will be added. See the c option, the format keyword args, and the format
 keyword comm.
